title: Chapter 141
content:
# Chapter 141

The journey to the Grey Forest took three days. Grid worked Jude and the soldiers relentlessly.

Malacus' Cloak drew monsters like flies to rot. Each time, Grid forced the soldiers to engage. It was brutal arithmetic. The Bairan monsters started at level 100; the Grey Forest edge crawled with monsters above 120. His soldiers? Level 70 to 80 at best.

They screamed. They bled. They begged for breaks that never came.

Grid ignored them. He never ordered a retreat. If they had to die fighting, so be it.

*They'll thank me later.*

The soldiers stopped calling him a hero. Now they muttered "devil" when they thought he couldn't hear.

On the surface, this expedition looked like torture. Yet none of them died. Every time a soldier teetered on death's edge, Grid or the knights intervened. Just enough. Never more than necessary.

Three days of this meat grinder pushed the average soldier level to 90. Jude, always in front, always bleeding, hit level 110.

Grid wiped sweat from his brow. *NPCs are different.*

Users got 10 stat points per level. Fixed. Predictable. But NPCs? The system rolled dice for them. Six to twenty points, random as hell. Every time Jude leveled, he scooped up at least 16 points.

*Yes. Keep growing, Jude. Then you'll be my faithful dog.*

---

The party reached the Grey Forest the next morning.

The soldiers' confidence evaporated the moment they saw the fog.

"I... I'm sorry, my lord. We can't go any further." A soldier's voice cracked.

Poison fog, courtesy of carnivorous flowers, blanketed the forest entrance. Three hundred meters of green death. Even standing five meters back, the soldiers' skin blistered. Health bars ticked downward in real time.

Romeo stepped forward, jaw tight. "My lord, without a Rebecca priest, we're dead men walking. The Guardian is out of reach. We should turn back."

The knights and soldiers stood frozen. Grid didn't push them.

*Poison fog deals 350 damage per second.*

The soldiers had less than 3,000 health. Forcing them in meant they'd be corpses before covering 100 meters. He'd spent three days training these men. No point wasting that now.

*I'll go alone.*

The poison flowers weren't just plants. They were level 160 predators, all tentacles and teeth, terror to travelers and monsters alike.

But Grid wasn't worried. His hand dipped into his inventory, fingers brushing Dainsleif's hilt. He'd clear a path.

"Jude?"

The captain walked past him. Toward the fog. Toward certain death.

The knights froze. Jude didn't.

*That's my man!* Grid grinned. *What trick does he have? Some hidden skill?*

Jude stepped into the fog.

His health bar plummeted like a stone down a well. He groaned. Took another step. Another. Then collapsed face-first into the grass.

"...What."

Grid blinked.

The soldiers erupted.

"The captain! He just—he's killing himself!"

"Rescue him! Now!"

"Are you insane? We go in there, we die too!"

"Gods, is he really going to die like this?"

Jude's health ticked down. 60%. 50%. 40%. The soldiers could only watch their captain choke on poison.

*Oh. Right.*

Grid's eye twitched. *He's just stupid.*

Three days of leveling, and Jude's intelligence still sat at 11. That skill—"I have no Idea"—wasn't a joke. The idiot hadn't marched into the fog because he had a plan. He'd marched in because he had *no plan*. No thought. Just forward.

"I can't lose him!"

Grid bolted.

"Viscount!" Romeo and Deck shouted in unison.

A viscount throwing himself into poison fog to save a common soldier? It defied logic. Defied every noble instinct.

Deck grabbed Romeo's arm. "Sir Romeo! If the viscount dies, we're finished!"

Romeo cursed. "Move—!"

Too late. Grid's agility stat wasn't for show. By the time Romeo processed the thought, Grid was already knee-deep in green death.

---

"Drink!"

Jude's vision swam. Pain crawled through every nerve. He tasted copper. Death felt close, warm, almost welcoming.

Then someone hauled him upright. Liquid fire poured down his throat. A potion.

Grid.

*A noble? For me?*

Jude had seen nobles use soldiers as meat shields. Expendable. Replaceable. Grid was different.

*Why?*

His 11 intelligence couldn't puzzle it out. So he just felt... grateful. Stupid and grateful.

Tentacles lashed toward them. Dozens. The poison flowers sensed prey.

None of the tentacles reached him.

"Pagma's Swordsmanship, Wave!"

Light erupted from Grid in a perfect circle. The tentacles disintegrated. The poison flowers *screamed*. Then the fog dissolved like it had never existed.

Clean air rushed into Jude's lungs. His high stamina kicked in, purging the poison. He stood, bowed his head.

"Thank you."

Grid stared at him. *Is that all you can say?*

"It's good to be brave." Grid's voice was tight. "But think before you act. You don't have ten lives."

"...Mm." Jude nodded.

But his expression was blank. Uncomprehending.

*He has no idea what I just said.*

Grid's jaw clenched. It wasn't a complex instruction. Just "be careful." How stupid did someone have to be to not understand that?

The knights and soldiers caught up, panting.

"You're alive!"

They stared at Grid like he'd split the sky.

"Dozens of poison flowers at once!" Romeo's eyes shone. "This is the man who defeated Malacus!"

"And he risked his life for a common soldier!" Deck added. "The epitome of nobility!"

"Viscount Grid! Viscount Grid!" The soldiers chanted.

Their devil had become a hero again. Grid forced a smile.

*Time to crush their hope.*

"See? With me, the Guardian of the Forest is easy."

"...Ah. Well." Romeo shifted his weight. "That is..."

Despite the display of power, doubt still flickered in their eyes.

Grid didn't wait for their answer. He just started walking deeper into the forest.

The knights and soldiers had no choice but to follow.

---

They found it in the forest's heart.

"Humans! No humans in forest! Humans pollute forest! No forgive humans!"

The goblin lord stood two meters tall, twice the height of his smaller kin. A level 180 field boss. The gatekeeper before the Guardian.

Hobgoblins materialized around him. Dozens of them.

Grid assessed the field, then barked orders. "Final training! Three soldiers per hobgoblin. Knights and Jude, watch the whole field. Help anyone in danger. When the goblin lord crouches, earthquake incoming. Spread out."

The pattern was identical to the Guardian of the Forest. Goblin lord summoned hobgoblins; Guardian summoned golems. Both used area-wide earthquake attacks.

Smart raid parties always fought the goblin lord first. Practice before the main event.

Grid had memorized every step.

"Move!"

The soldiers and knights swarmed the hobgoblins. Grid closed on the goblin lord.

*Pagma's Swordsmanship, Kill.*

> [Critical!]
> 
> [The Holy Light Gloves option effect is activated, causing you to attack the target five times.]
> 
> [You have dealt 302,555 damage.]
> 
> [You have defeated the Guard of the Grey Forest, the Goblin Lord!]
> 
> [2,600,100 experience has been acquired.]
> 
> [The Goblin Lord's Club has been acquired.]
> 
> [The Goblin Lord's Fang has been acquired.]
> 
> [Your level has risen.]

"...Fuck."

The critical hit. The Holy Light Gloves' five-strike chain. Kill's absurd multiplier. The combo that had crippled a level 280 griffon boss now annihilated a level 180 field boss in one blow.

*I didn't mean to.*

He'd wanted to wound it. Train the soldiers. Not delete the damn thing from existence.

"Hiik! Humans! Scary!" The hobgoblins scattered like roaches in light.

Grid's eye twitched. *Should've taken the gloves off.*

The opportunity to train them, wasted. The knights and soldiers just stared.

*Is that even human?*

*Ridiculously strong...*

"The Guardian of the Forest." Grid dusted off his hands. "Time to hunt it."

Amid the stunned silence, only Jude moved forward.

Without thinking.

As always.
